poll_list.title: Maker Teleport Deployment on Starknet and Associated Risk Parameters - August 1, 2022

discourse_list.title: Request to Poll for Maker teleport Deployment on Starknet and Associated Risk Parameters

content.content: Request to Poll for Maker teleport Deployment on Starknet and Associated Risk Parameters In support of MIP69: L2 to L1 Fast Withdrawals 18, Starknet Engineering Core Unit is requesting to poll on the following parameters as part of the weekly governance cycle, which if successful will allow this to proceed to an on-chain vote. The reason for introducing this poll before Fast withdrawals are released on mainnet is that the technical work has been underway for sometime and is known by the community but requires a formal poll to proceed with the defined risk parameters. Completing this formality now will enable Maker to vote on the deployment once it is ready, for which we are targeting end of August.  Parameter Summary SNE-001 (Starknet Engineering Core Unit) is requesting Governance to poll on approving L2 to L1 Fast Withdrawals, including: Approve the following gateways (domains), as documented in MIP69 19 and the github implementation: Starknet A thorough risk assessment has been undergone and discussed on the forum on this post from PECU and SECU: Fast withdrawals and risk assumptions. Debt Ceiling Parameters:  Set the Starknet Debt Ceiling parameter to 1M Dai Set the Global Debt Ceiling to 3M Dai - as a sum of all debt ceilings for each domain. The current Global Debt Ceiling is set to 2Mn (1Mn for Optimism, and 1Mn for Arbitrum)  Wormhole Fee Parameters per Domain:  Set the Starknet teleport Fee parameter to 0 bps  Approve Oracle Quorum of (13) feeds (see details from the Oracle CU here)  This is the minimum number of feed attestations required to complete a Fast Withdrawal transaction and will be comprised of any of the 25 oracle feeds provided by the Oracles team.   Details:  A conservative 1M Dai debt ceiling for Optimism and Arbitrum domains has been applied. This has been chosen to limit Fast Withdrawal risk and will be increased once the teleport has been upgraded to support oracle hard confirmations and the market has shown demand for greater usage. The current implementation is based on oracle soft confirmations requiring complete trust in the sequencer to include confirmed transactions that burn DAI. PECU and SECU have published a Fast withdrawals risks and asumptions post, explaining the rationale for having the same debt ceiling of 1Mn Dai for Starknet, Optimism, and Arbitrum The wormhole fee is an absolute amount and is levied per domain. This could be upgraded in the future if the need arises. This fee is only applied to fast withdrawals. The slow withdrawals bridge, which requires a 7 day wait will continue to function without fees even if fees are introduced for Fast Withdrawals.
content.GPT-summary: The Starknet Engineering Core Unit is requesting a poll to approve L2 to L1 Fast Withdrawals, including approving gateways, setting debt ceiling parameters, and approving Oracle Quorum. A risk assessment has been undergone and discussed, and a conservative 1M Dai debt ceiling has been applied for Optimism and Arbitrum domains. The wormhole fee is an absolute amount and is levied per domain, and is only applied to fast withdrawals.
GPT-discussion-categories: Author of proposal is explaining proposal

content.content: First structured product on StarkNet and it includes DAI  Return of the Jedi I mean, it’s a work in progress and a bit of a griefing issue—but it’s a start.
GPT-discussion-categories: 3rd party giving constructive criticism of proposal

content.content: Please outline whether there is a multisig that is capable of disrupting the continuity of the Starknet (altering transactions, rolling back the state, etc), who controls the keys, what jurisdiction they reside in, and what counter-incentive they have to avoid collusion or theft of funds. Also please advise whether Starknet would be willing to enter into a legal agreement with MakerDAO that would provide necessary assurances that funds would remain safe and keep MKR holders from having to implicitly trust the multisig signers.
GPT-discussion-categories: 3rd party asking questions about proposal
3rd party giving constructive criticism of proposal
3rd party or author wants to collaborate on proposal
3rd party auditing and reviewing proposal
None of the topics listed match

content.content: GovAlpha Summary:  This proposal seeks to set parameters related to Maker Teleport deployment on Starknet. The relevant parameter changes are listed in the post. It falls under the mandate of the requesting facilitator and is therefore eligible to proceed on-chain as a weekly poll (see MIP16 for further details on this process). This poll will go on-chain on 2022-08-01 and run for three days. The proposal has been assigned a High Impact rating as it contains risk-related parameter changes.
GPT-discussion-categories: 3rd party auditing and reviewing proposal

content.content: @ChrisBlec thank you for bringing those points up. I am collecting the information from Starkware and will revert re: rights over the sequencer. I think those are very relevant questions for any rollups given that most of them only have one sequencer at the moment. The premise of the L2 risk management strategy is that we trust sequencers for the time being, hence companies building the rollups. The bridge limit (for simple bridge) and debt ceiling (for fast withdrawals) should be seen as risk parameters defining “what we are ready to put at stake given what we know of the trust assumptions”. Those risk parameters will evolve as the rollup evolve through mechanisms reducing the trust assumptions, and execute their decentralization roadmap. Starkware is a $8Bn company, making revenues from Starkex, but arguably having most of its valuation relying on the Starknet rollup strategy. They are also funding 50/50 the SECU. What is there to gain here is to rug 1Mn DAI (in fact 200k DAI which is the bridge limit), what is there to lose is $Bn and the funding they provided to SECU so far. The bridge limit and fast withdrawals will be increased once we are more comfortable with trust assumptions, specifically with the development of the following features: ability to insert forced transactions from L1 (similarly to the Canonical transaction chain on Optimism), the checkpoint mechanism by which a sequencer commits to the order and the transactions included in the next batch, and sequencer decentralization cc @Primoz @Derek
GPT-discussion-categories: Author of proposal is explaining proposal

content.content: pyramidmaker:  @ChrisBlec thank you for bringing those points up. I am collecting the information from Starkware and will revert re: rights over the sequencer. I think those are very relevant questions for any rollups given that most of them only have one sequencer at the moment.   Thank you. Just want to note that my question isn’t limited to sequencer - it is specifically about a multisig or other admin control that is capable of altering the logic or state of the network.     pyramidmaker:  Starkware is a $8Bn company, making revenues from Starkex, but arguably having most of its valuation relying on the Starknet rollup strategy. They are also funding 50/50 the SECU. What is there to gain here is to rug 1Mn DAI (in fact 200k DAI which is the bridge limit), what is there to lose is $Bn and the funding they provided to SECU so far.   My concerns are not necessarily about the Starkware team rugging. Mistakes happen, as do other forms of attack. If there is a multisig, it can be compromised inadvertantly, or it can be used to comply with a forcible request from a state actor. MKR holders need to understand all possible attack vectors. Thanks again.
GPT-discussion-categories: 3rd party giving constructive criticism of proposal

content.content: I’ll get those answers for you @ChrisBlec , thanks for bringing those up. Very valid, and would be worthwhile to answer those across rollups

Just want to point out that Wormhole is not used anymore as far as I know. Should be teleport right?     Maker Wormhole new name: Maker Teleport Growth       Hi, Maker fam.  As you may know, the Protocol Engineering Core Unit is working to build a product that will allow DAI transfers across Layer 2 domains. As described in this post, the name chosen for this product was Maker Wormhole.  Nevertheless, Jump Trading has been building a bridge product with a similar name for quite some time. They also acquired the domain wormhole.com as part of its branding strategy.  This is why between the Brand Team and Protocol Engineering Core Unit we decided to re…

content.content: Good point @RoFz - we’re still using wormhole in discussions hence the mistake. Fixed it and will be careful going forward

Great initiative to add support for StarkNet given the traction that ecosystem is seeing. Two quick questions:  What testing has been / will be conducted of Maker Oracle’s ability to handle L2 → L1 ‘soft’ confirmations? Seems likely that a tx oracle will be substantially more complex than a price oracle and embed greater risk, how will this be reflected in the chosen parameters? In light of the fact that most activity on StarkNet still occurs on Goerli testnet rather than mainnet, what are the plans for rollout across the main / testnet?
GPT-discussion-categories: 3rd party asking questions about proposal
3rd party giving constructive criticism of proposal

content.content: Are we going for 0 teleport fees now? I though we wanted to go for something like 1 bps? (IIRC for Optimism and Arbitrum)

Thanks @park for those questions, answers below  We have been testing on testnet extensively. More tests won’t solve this problem, rather rollups changing their design and reducing the trust assumptions will. On Starknet side, a checkpoint mechanism (by which the sequencer commits to include a series of transactions in the next batch) and decentralization will reduce the trust assumptions.  Note that in the current implementation of Optimism, Arbitrum, and Starknet, the risk profiles are very similar for all the rollups (see Fast withdrawal risk assessment). The debt ceiling will be increased as the rollups implement their roadmap and reduce the risk for MKR holders.  PECU is planning to release fast withdrawals on mainnet, we are planning to release fast withdrawals on Starknet mainnet 1-2 weeks after that. Starknet mainnet might undergo a state reset before the end of the year, which will happen in parallel with the release of important features (forced transactions, proving false transactions, decentralization roadmap). Hence we will not significantly increase the bridge limit and debt ceiling before then. We will propose a migration path to all users prior to the state reset.
GPT-discussion-categories: Author of proposal is explaining proposal

content.content: Currently it’s zero for optimism and arbitrum as well. Getting back to you on timing for non-zero value.
@GWintery , I checked with PECU today and we aligned on 1 bps. Thanks for catching it, just edited the poll

@pyramidmaker, the poll had already been live for over a day before this change was made, and the poll has attracted a number of votes already. At this stage, it is too late to amend the polled parameters unless we cancel the whole poll. I suggest we poll again on the fee before the Teleport implementation goes live. I understand we have several weeks before the projected go-live date, so there is plenty of time to run another poll on the fee parameter. Please correct me if I’m wrong.

content.content: MIP16 allows Core Unit Facilitators to propose polls that may enter the weekly cycle without needing a Signal Request. This was the governance process being utilised in this case.

@Patrick_J @flipflopflapdelegate apologies for the confusion. I checked with the GovAlpha that I was clear to submit directly. Let’s keep 0 bps and I will submit another poll to change to 1bps. PECU will deploy on mainnet on August 17 and we will deploy early September so we have 4 weeks. Thank you both for your comments

content.content: pyramidmaker:  I’ll get those answers for you @ChrisBlec , thanks for bringing those up. Very valid, and would be worthwhile to answer those across rollups   It’s time to vote and I still didn’t get an answer to this important question. This is an absolutely critical piece of info. I don’t understand how anyone can vote to deploy this bridge without knowing whether or not the core logic of Starknet can be manipulated by a 3rd party multisig or admin key. If anyone has the info, please share.
GPT-discussion-categories: 3rd party asking questions about proposal
3rd party giving constructive criticism of proposal

content.content: ChrisBlec:  It’s time to vote and I still didn’t get an answer to this important question. This is an absolutely critical piece of info. I don’t understand how anyone can vote to deploy this bridge without knowing whether or not the core logic of Starknet can be manipulated by a 3rd party multisig or admin key. If anyone has the info, please share.   Hey Chris! A pleasure to meet you, Ohad from StarkWare here! The “core logic of StarkNet” can’t be tempered in subtle ways. StarkWare can’t use its control over the sequencer for inserting invalid transactions and steal money. It can’t roll the state back. This is enforced by STARK proofs, which are the base for scalable self-custodial solutions deployed by us over the last several years The only (theoretical) way to steal DAI from the system is by replacing the L1 core contract. This measure would be very visible to detect, and we usually notify about a few days ahead. The upgrade is done by a cold key, and you will thus have evidence of the tempering and the state before the update that can be used for compensation. This risk is fully detailed in @pyramidmaker risk analysis.
GPT-discussion-categories: 3rd party asking questions about proposal
3rd party giving constructive criticism of proposal

content.content: @ChrisBlec feel free to ask anything else!

Thanks for the response.     Ohad_Barta_StarkWare:  The upgrade is done by a cold key, and you will thus have evidence of the tempering and the state before the update that can be used for compensation.   Based on this I’m led to believe that there is an EOA that is capable of upgrading the core contract. I believe that admin keys like this one should be treated with the same level of scrutiny as any TradFi bank or institution. So, why should MKR holders trust Starknet’s EOA admin key without any sort of legal agreement with whoever is securing it? What reason, aside from “we’d never do that”, is there to trust that it’s being held securely, safely and will only be used with integrity? Thanks again for engaging.
GPT-discussion-categories: 3rd party giving constructive criticism of proposal
3rd party asking questions about proposal

content.content: The cold key is treated the same way any other system’s cold key we have is treated, these measurements have proven useful and effective for the two years+ we have systems on mainnet. As for a reason - TBH it’s only the “we would never do it” reason, but I think our entire way of thinking and operating has shown the deepest respect to our user’s funds. As an example, we started with a really harsh TVL cap on our bridges a few months back - and we increased it very slowly and gradually to be sure we don’t lose more than what is manageable before making more security efforts. We are well aware that even if you put the entire DAI surplus on StarkNet, we have much more to lose than to gain. We are continuously working on improving the security of StarkNet , and our TVL (as well as the cap on yours) should reflect the current condition/status of the network.
GPT-discussion-categories: 3rd party giving constructive criticism of proposal
3rd party asking questions about proposal

content.content: Ohad_Barta_StarkWare:  As for a reason - TBH it’s only the “we would never do it” reason   Thank you for the honest response. Because there is no valid reason for MKR holders to trust in the uncompromisability of Starknet’s god-mode admin key, and no legal agreement in place to secure MKR holders rights (as there is with every RWA agreement), I’ll have to vote against and would encourage other delegates to do the same. This is far too much unsubstantiated trust for delegates to force upon MKR holders. This goes for Starknet, Arbitrum, Optimism or any other admin-key-controlled L2.
GPT-discussion-categories: 3rd party giving negative feedback on proposal
3rd party giving constructive criticism of proposal
3rd party asking questions about proposal

content.content: @ChrisBlec All the rollups are young emerging technologies. Maker is making a bet on those because the opportunity cost of not going to promising L2s is much higher than staying on L1. The consensus between PECU/SECU/Risk CU is that the way to control for risk is by having tight bridge limits and fast withdrawal debt ceiling. Again, this 1mn DAI limit is in fact 200k DAI limit given that it’s the current simple bridge limit. Given the multi $Bn reputational damage for Starkware of rugging DAI here, it has not felt necessary to setup a legal framework. Rather we have decided to limit the risk until the technical trust assumptions are reduced.  We will only consider raising the risk parameters once trust assumptions improve through e.g., checkpoints, forced L1 transactions, and decentralization. However, always happy to be challenged and I am glad you’re bringing those points up. I will discuss with PECU and Risk CU how we can provide more visibility here.
GPT-discussion-categories: Author of proposal is explaining proposal

content.content: “NEVER” might be a bit strong. In this instance, isn’t “most of the technical work is already done, setting up a legal framework would take time, there is huge upside in launching early, and the worst case is capped to losses that MakerDAO can happily walk away from” a good reason?

content.content: Our direction has been to not setup a legal framework and only scale the risk parameters once there is no need for a legal framework because trust assumptions have disappeared. We have been working on a mitigation framework to define how we would jointly with the rollups react to a hack. To be posted soon. However I appreciate the comments on having a more rigorous agreement there and @Derek and I will discuss this. The post on the mitigation will be a good place to pick up this discussion
